required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Inflammatory Responses Subsequent to Different Cesarean Section Techniques
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Inflammatory Reactions Following Two Different Cesarean Surgery Techniques; The Modified Misgav-Ladach Versus the Pfannenstiel-Kerr Technique

detailed_description.textblock: Cesarean section is one of the most undertaken operations in women of childbearing age. However, there is not a unique cesarean surgery technique. Pfannenstiel , reported his own technique in 1897. Because of the applicability of the technique, it went down well among obstetricians. After three decades, Kerr evolved this technique, and Pfannenstiel-Kerr technique became the method of choice until late 70's. In 1972, Stark et al defined the Misgav Ladach technique and in the following years this technique became popular among obstetricians. In late 80's Misgav Ladach technique was modified and started to be more popular. But, still Pfannenstiel-Kerr technique continued to be used frequently and studies comparing clinical outcomes of these two techniques were conducted for several times. However, the inflammatory responses which occured subsequent to application of these techniques were not investigated. This is the first study investigating the inflammatory response emerged after different cesarean surgery techniques.

primary_outcome.description: percentage of difference in serum IL-6 levels just before the beginning of the surgery and at the 24th hour of the surgery
percentage of difference in serum IL-6 levels just before the beginning of the surgery and at the 24th hour of the surgery

arm_group.description: cesarean section(C/S) via the modified 'Misgav-Ladach' technique

intervention.intervention_name: cesarean section(C/S) via the modified Misgav-Ladach technique
intervention.description: the first consecutive 44 patients underwent C/S via the modified Misgav-Ladach technique

intervention.intervention_name: cesarean section via the Pfannenstiel-Kerr technique
intervention.description: the second consecutive 44 patients underwent C/S via the Pfannenstiel-Kerr technique

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Cesarean section for the first time
- Term,singleton pregnancy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Any inflammatory disease
- Any pregnancy complication; IUGR,preeclampsia,preterm labor,preterm premature rupture of membranes
- Pregnancies <37weeks gestational age
